title: 106_hr909
content: The Act may be cited as the "Y2K State and Local GAP (Government Assistance Programs) Act of 1999". Definitions are provided in the Act. The Act, known as the "Y2K State and Local GAP Act of 1999," outlines various welfare programs including TANF, Medicaid, food stamps, WIC, and child support enforcement. The Child Nutrition Act of 1966, child support enforcement, child welfare programs, and child care programs are outlined in the Y2K State and Local GAP Act of 1999. The term "Y2K compliant" refers to information technology accurately processing date and time data between the 20th and 21st centuries, including leap year calculations. Grants will be provided to states to ensure that state and local government programs are Y2K compliant. The Secretary of Commerce will award grants to states for Y2K compliance in state and local government programs, with priority given to Federal welfare programs. Limitations include a maximum of 75 grants overall, 2 grants per state, and an application deadline of 45 days after enactment. The application deadline for a grant authorized under this section is 45 days after enactment. A State can submit an application through the State Governor's Office, following the constraints outlined by the Secretary of Commerce. The application must include a proposed plan for Y2K compliance, a budget, and a specific funding request. The application for a grant under this section must include a proposed plan for Y2K compliance, a budget, and a specific funding request. A State awarded a grant must match $1 for every $2 awarded for the development and implementation of a Y2K compliance program. The Secretary of Commerce may waive the matching requirement for states facing hardship. The Secretary of Commerce may waive or modify the matching requirement for states facing hardship. State expenditures required under the grant may be in cash or in kind, including equipment or services. Only expenditures made after the grant has been awarded can be counted towards meeting the requirement. The Secretary of Commerce may waive or modify the matching requirement for states facing hardship. State expenditures required under the grant may be in cash or in kind, including equipment or services. Grants awarded under this section are limited to a maximum of 2 years, and funds provided to a State shall remain available until expended without fiscal year limitation. Each State awarded a grant must submit an annual report. The Secretary of Commerce may waive or modify the matching requirement for states facing hardship. Each State awarded a grant must submit an annual report. Grantees must submit annual reports to the Secretary of Commerce, and a final report evaluating the programs funded under the grants is required within 90 days after the termination of all grants. $40,000,000 is authorized to be appropriated for fiscal years 1999 to 2001 to carry out this section.
